nodes.label: Configuration 1 performed better at creative, unconstrained generation of the ca...
nodes.detail: Configuration 1 performed better at creative, unconstrained generation of the capability map, but was semantically unverified.

nodes.label: Configuration 2 offered semantic alignment and potential ontology alignment of c...
nodes.detail: Configuration 2 offered semantic alignment and potential ontology alignment of capabilities, but it is limited to level 1.

nodes.label: We observe that when EKG is not incorporated into the agent architecture (i.e., ...
nodes.detail: We observe that when EKG is not incorporated into the agent architecture (i.e., Configuration 1 using ToT-prompted agents), entity extraction can be completed using the user query; however, it lacks semantic precision due to the absence of external grounding.

nodes.label: Configuration 2 addressed this by integrating an EKG, grounding the entities usi...
nodes.detail: Configuration 2 addressed this by integrating an EKG, grounding the entities using organisational ontologies and improving the validity of generated output.

nodes.label: These observations suggest that ABMA's modular architecture and agent orchestrat...
nodes.detail: These observations suggest that ABMA's modular architecture and agent orchestration proved effective for scalable and context-aware capability mapping.

nodes.label: The use of LLMs combined with structured knowledge significantly improved the ac...
nodes.detail: The use of LLMs combined with structured knowledge significantly improved the accuracy and adaptability of generated BCMs.

nodes.label: We plan to extend our implementation to additional BA artefact agents, aiming to...
nodes.detail: We plan to extend our implementation to additional BA artefact agents, aiming to develop a more intelligent and autonomous BA method.

nodes.label: The end goal of this project is to provide architecture that can be adapted by B...
nodes.detail: The end goal of this project is to provide architecture that can be adapted by BA experts who are interested in automating their modelling process, while incorporating context-aware reasoning that enables trust in the system.

nodes.label: Economist Impact (2024)
nodes.detail: Unlocking Enterprise AI: Opportunities and Strategies

nodes.label: The present trajectory of artificial intelligence — investment, adoption, and re...
nodes.detail: The present trajectory of artificial intelligence — investment, adoption, and results — makes abundantly clear that the technology is going to become an integral part of every business, irrespective of industry.

nodes.label: Success in this new landscape will require business leaders to do far more than ...
nodes.detail: Success in this new landscape will require business leaders to do far more than adopt the latest and greatest AI model.

nodes.label: Winners in each industry will be those who take a holistic approach that encompa...
nodes.detail: Winners in each industry will be those who take a holistic approach that encompasses data management, security, governance, culture, and domain-specific expertise.

nodes.label: A key finding from this report is that companies overwhelmingly want to integrat...
nodes.detail: A key finding from this report is that companies overwhelmingly want to integrate generative AI models with their own data, which requires modernising their enterprise data platform — addressing the problem of fragmentation and advancing beyond the capabilities of a single large commercial model.

nodes.label: The future also lies in AI systems and agents comprising multiple components, us...
nodes.detail: The future also lies in AI systems and agents comprising multiple components, using custom models, each optimised for specific tasks — this approach allows for greater accuracy, cost, performance and security.

nodes.label: Democratisation is a big driver for AI — organisations want to make data more ac...
nodes.detail: Democratisation is a big driver for AI — organisations want to make data more accessible to a wider range of employees and look to empower their people to build and refine AI models that reflect their day-to-day business needs.

nodes.label: The future lies not only with AI models trained on web data, but with true data ...
nodes.detail: The future lies not only with AI models trained on web data, but with true data intelligence — systems that deeply understand and operate on an organisation's specific, often sensitive data sets.

nodes.label: A heady US$1trn in capital expenditure is expected in the coming years to delive...
nodes.detail: A heady US$1trn in capital expenditure is expected in the coming years to deliver the data centres, chips, energy and infrastructure to support the artificial intelligence (AI) revolution.

nodes.label: The difference now is democratisation and scale — because GenAI provides an intu...
nodes.detail: The difference now is democratisation and scale — because GenAI provides an intuitive, natural language interface, the benefits of AI have become accessible to every practitioner.

nodes.label: To transition successfully from pilots to enterprise-wide deployment requires a ...
nodes.detail: To transition successfully from pilots to enterprise-wide deployment requires a robust infrastructure that can handle the data and computational requirements of AI, a workforce strategy that appropriately calibrates humans versus machines, and an appropriate return on investment (ROI) strategy.

nodes.label: Achieving AI excellence necessitates strong governance and careful design of hum...
nodes.detail: Achieving AI excellence necessitates strong governance and careful design of human machine interaction — decisions and outputs must comply with extensive existing and emerging legislation in areas like data privacy, security and consumer protection.

nodes.label: 85% of organisations are actively using GenAI in at least one business function,...
nodes.detail: 85% of organisations are actively using GenAI in at least one business function, reaching 97% among companies with revenue over US$10bn.

nodes.label: IT teams are the most avid adopters and the legal function is the most reticent.
nodes.detail: IT teams are the most avid adopters and the legal function is the most reticent.

nodes.label: Internal projects are preferred but, by 2027, 99% of executives expect GenAI ado...
nodes.detail: Internal projects are preferred but, by 2027, 99% of executives expect GenAI adoption across internal and external use cases.

nodes.label: Seven in ten see AI as crucial to their long-term strategic goals, and only 18% ...
nodes.detail: Seven in ten see AI as crucial to their long-term strategic goals, and only 18% say it is overhyped.

nodes.label: Despite the momentum, only one in five believe that their current investment acr...
nodes.detail: Despite the momentum, only one in five believe that their current investment across technical and non-technical domains is sufficient.

nodes.label: So far, productivity is one of the most commonly reported impacts of AI — functi...
nodes.detail: So far, productivity is one of the most commonly reported impacts of AI — functions with high automation potential have been heavily testing GenAI, such as IT (91%), marketing (85%), sales and customer service (83%), and operations (80%), while 82% of data scientists report using AI for coding.

nodes.label: Revenue growth has been the least effective metric for justifying investment to ...
nodes.detail: Revenue growth has been the least effective metric for justifying investment to date, with experts arguing that AI returns will take time to accrue given the need for experimentation, iteration and digital infrastructure overhauls.

nodes.label: Strategic considerations like business model innovation, market positioning, and...
nodes.detail: Strategic considerations like business model innovation, market positioning, and environment, social and governance standards have been the most important elements when evaluating business cases for AI.

nodes.label: Many enterprises are operating with the technological equivalent of Victorian-er...
nodes.detail: Many enterprises are operating with the technological equivalent of Victorian-era plumbing — only 22% of organisations say their current architecture can support AI workloads without modifications, and 48% of data engineers spend most of their time resolving data source connections.

nodes.label: The problem could worsen as democratisation leads to a proliferation of AI pilot...
nodes.detail: The problem could worsen as democratisation leads to a proliferation of AI pilots, leading to congestion, complexity, and opacity in data and infrastructure.

nodes.label: Two-thirds of organisations see significant potential in integrating GenAI model...
nodes.detail: Two-thirds of organisations see significant potential in integrating GenAI models with their own data — as AI models become commoditised, the best performers will mix and match models and tools with their unique assets: proprietary data and know-how.

nodes.label: Nearly seven out of ten are experimenting with or have fully deployed open-sourc...
nodes.detail: Nearly seven out of ten are experimenting with or have fully deployed open-source GenAI, with 96% believing they will do so by 2027.

nodes.label: Off-the-shelf models, unconnected to enterprise data, are still common: almost h...
nodes.detail: Off-the-shelf models, unconnected to enterprise data, are still common: almost half (45%) of data scientists are using large language models (LLMs) without retrieval augmented generation (RAG).

nodes.label: Only 37% of executives believe their GenAI applications are production-ready, a ...
nodes.detail: Only 37% of executives believe their GenAI applications are production-ready, a figure that falls to just 29% among practitioners.

nodes.label: Data scientists cite key constraints including cost (41%), skills (40%), quality...
nodes.detail: Data scientists cite key constraints including cost (41%), skills (40%), quality (37%) and governance (33%).

nodes.label: Only one in six respondents believe that their organisation can secure enough AI...
nodes.detail: Only one in six respondents believe that their organisation can secure enough AI talent.

nodes.label: Half of data engineers say governance takes up more time than anything else, and...
nodes.detail: Half of data engineers say governance takes up more time than anything else, and more than half of enterprise architects (53%) cite challenges with data privacy and security breaches as the biggest risk of AI expansion.

nodes.label: Leaders say AI can augment rather than replace employees — interviewees cite uni...
nodes.detail: Leaders say AI can augment rather than replace employees — interviewees cite unified systems and 'centres of excellence' as critical to balancing governance and enablement.

nodes.label: Two-thirds of organisations say they are still experimenting to find the right b...
nodes.detail: Two-thirds of organisations say they are still experimenting to find the right balance between humans and AI.

nodes.label: Enterprise architects see GenAI as a democratising force, with nearly 60% predic...
nodes.detail: Enterprise architects see GenAI as a democratising force, with nearly 60% predicting that within three years natural language will be the primary — if not only — way that non-technical staff interact with complex datasets.

nodes.label: The GenAI breakthrough took AI from narrow tasks performed by expert teams to a ...
nodes.detail: The GenAI breakthrough took AI from narrow tasks performed by expert teams to a capability available to nearly everyone.

nodes.label: Novartis has been using machine learning (ML) for drug discovery and predictive ...
nodes.detail: Novartis has been using machine learning (ML) for drug discovery and predictive analytics to improve clinical trials; Flo Health's global consumer-facing women's health app used by over 380 million people is based on an algorithm using traditional ML techniques.

nodes.label: 73% say GenAI is critical to their long-term strategic goals; only 18% say AI is...
nodes.detail: 73% say GenAI is critical to their long-term strategic goals; only 18% say AI is overhyped — executives are slightly more cautious (20% lean towards hype) than data and AI technologists (just 13%).

metadata.section: Ch1: Executives and practitioners believe AI has proven value

nodes.label: In the years ahead, winners and losers will be defined by who is able to graduat...
nodes.detail: In the years ahead, winners and losers will be defined by who is able to graduate from experiments to implementation at scale.

metadata.section: Ch1: Executives and practitioners believe AI has proven value

nodes.label: 85% of organisations are testing and using GenAI today, with adoption rates clim...
nodes.detail: 85% of organisations are testing and using GenAI today, with adoption rates climbing as company size increases — among those with revenue over US$10bn, 97% are testing and using it.

nodes.label: GenAI usage is most advanced among IT teams, with 62% having fully deployed it; ...
nodes.detail: GenAI usage is most advanced among IT teams, with 62% having fully deployed it; marketing and sales, including customer service, are leading adoption ahead of other business teams.

nodes.label: Flo Health has seen a 24% boost in data engineering efficiency, with AI assistan...
nodes.detail: Flo Health has seen a 24% boost in data engineering efficiency, with AI assistants reducing mistakes and accelerating document generation.

nodes.label: Repsol ran a GenAI experiment with 200 coders and more than 200,000 lines of cod...
nodes.detail: Repsol ran a GenAI experiment with 200 coders and more than 200,000 lines of code across 20 programming languages, finding improvements in productivity of up to 30%, with an average of 7%.

nodes.label: 'Agentic AI' — artificial agents with a natural language interface that can plan...
nodes.detail: 'Agentic AI' — artificial agents with a natural language interface that can plan and execute sequences of actions on behalf of a user — will become an increasingly common feature of daily life, surpassing text-to-speech applications like Alexa and Siri in scope and smarts.

nodes.label: More than 97% of enterprise architects predict that non-technical staff will use...
nodes.detail: More than 97% of enterprise architects predict that non-technical staff will use natural language programmes to interact with complex datasets within the next three years; nearly six in ten (58%) say natural language will be either the primary or only way they do this.

nodes.label: Figure 1: Stage of GenAI adoption by business function — IT: 62% in production, ...
nodes.detail: Figure 1: Stage of GenAI adoption by business function — IT: 62% in production, 29% experimenting; Marketing: 40% in production, 46% experimenting; Sales/customer service: 39% in production, 43% experimenting; Operations/supply chain: 32% in production, 48% experimenting; HR: 24% in production, 42% experimenting; R&D: 23% in production, 27% experimenting; Finance: 21% in production, 25% experimenting; Legal: 11% in production, 20% experimenting.

nodes.label: Financial services leads all other industries in GenAI implementation — 45% are ...
nodes.detail: Financial services leads all other industries in GenAI implementation — 45% are already expanding and scaling production of use cases and another 36% are in active deployment.

nodes.label: Figure 2: Stage of GenAI implementation by industry — Financial services: 45% ex...
nodes.detail: Figure 2: Stage of GenAI implementation by industry — Financial services: 45% expanding, 36% deploying; Telecoms: 40% expanding, 36% deploying; Retail: 35% expanding, 42% deploying; Manufacturing: 34% expanding, 41% deploying; Healthcare: 23% expanding, 42% deploying; Energy: 16% expanding, 49% deploying; Government: 7% expanding, 50% deploying; Media: 4% expanding, 60% deploying.

nodes.label: In India, most companies (56%) are scaling up GenAI, relying on public and open-...
nodes.detail: In India, most companies (56%) are scaling up GenAI, relying on public and open-source models much more than organisations in other countries; in Japan just 6% are scaling up, reflecting the country's preference for more complex, customised models.

nodes.label: Risk management was a dominant strategic area in which AI as a whole is informin...
nodes.detail: Risk management was a dominant strategic area in which AI as a whole is informing decisions at companies of all sizes, reported by 68%, followed by market entry (66%), and strategic sales and partnerships (66%).

nodes.label: Larger companies are more likely to use AI for strategic decisions around produc...
nodes.detail: Larger companies are more likely to use AI for strategic decisions around product development (67%), hiring and workforce planning (67%), and investment and capital allocation (61%) compared with mid-size companies (55%, 53% and 48%, respectively).

nodes.label: JetBlue has developed digital twins — ML-powered replicas of physical systems — ...
nodes.detail: JetBlue has developed digital twins — ML-powered replicas of physical systems — to enhance predictive capabilities in an industry rife with unexpected disruptions from weather events to technical issues.

nodes.label: Mastercard uses GenAI to enhance and speed up card fraud detection — scanning a ...
nodes.detail: Mastercard uses GenAI to enhance and speed up card fraud detection — scanning a trillion data points globally to predict whether a transaction is genuine or not.

nodes.label: General Motors uses ML to analyse diagnostic data to predict issues before they ...
nodes.detail: General Motors uses ML to analyse diagnostic data to predict issues before they become serious — anticipating if a vehicle battery on the production line will have problems so it can be removed and fixed before being installed in a car.

nodes.label: Mahindra Group uses AI to analyse publicly available and proprietary data to mak...
nodes.detail: Mahindra Group uses AI to analyse publicly available and proprietary data to make lending decisions, creating credit scores that could promote financial inclusion.

nodes.label: Siam Commercial Bank used ML to reduce credit underwriting costs by 20%.
nodes.detail: Siam Commercial Bank used ML to reduce credit underwriting costs by 20%.

nodes.label: Unilever is embedding AI-driven intelligence into its decision-making process th...
nodes.detail: Unilever is embedding AI-driven intelligence into its decision-making process through the Horizon3 Lab for identifying and testing new AI concepts, and its Sky programme leveraging advanced analytics to optimise its product portfolio.

nodes.label: Whether in productivity or in prototyping, companies are picking their pilots ca...
nodes.detail: Whether in productivity or in prototyping, companies are picking their pilots carefully — Providence, a healthcare organisation, explains its approach of being 'very methodical and very intentional' to avoid the mindset of 'spray and pray'.

nodes.label: Many companies prefer internal-facing applications before releasing products to ...
nodes.detail: Many companies prefer internal-facing applications before releasing products to customers — TD Bank Group has deployed a GenAI chatbot for its call centre but has kept it internal.

nodes.label: The US Department of Defense (DoD) draws a line between administrative and battl...
nodes.detail: The US Department of Defense (DoD) draws a line between administrative and battlefield applications, with far higher stakes associated with decision support in warfare.

nodes.label: Accenture sees a distinction between 'table stakes' use cases (optimising custom...
nodes.detail: Accenture sees a distinction between 'table stakes' use cases (optimising customer contact centre operations, marketing functions, coding workflows) and 'strategic bets' representing more innovative and experimental use cases.

nodes.label: Sandbox environments are one mechanism for AI experimentation — HP today support...
nodes.detail: Sandbox environments are one mechanism for AI experimentation — HP today supports 75 private sandboxes for a variety of uses, all in the name of testing and exploring AI possibilities in a safe, secure and robust environment.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Take a stake-based approach to experimentation — firms are focusin...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Take a stake-based approach to experimentation — firms are focusing on internal use-cases in lower-stakes domains as they ascend the maturation curve, and should focus on small, tightly scoped, problem-oriented projects.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Sandboxes and centralised oversight for pilots can help coordinate...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Sandboxes and centralised oversight for pilots can help coordinate experiments — 'letting a hundred flowers bloom' could impede long-term coherence and governance of AI projects.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: In a volatile world, AI can parse signal from noise — firms relian...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: In a volatile world, AI can parse signal from noise — firms reliant on international supply chains and sensitive to economic and political headwinds are leaning on AI to inform decision-making.

nodes.label: Internal operational improvements have been the initial focus, but companies are...
nodes.detail: Internal operational improvements have been the initial focus, but companies are now shifting towards external AI applications that could drive significant revenue growth and unlock value from previously untapped data sources.

nodes.label: Revenue growth has been the least important metric for AI investment to date, wi...
nodes.detail: Revenue growth has been the least important metric for AI investment to date, with only 19% of respondents agreeing that it has significantly contributed to the investment case.

nodes.label: Figure 4: Revenue growth is not yet a leading driver of AI investment decisions ...
nodes.detail: Figure 4: Revenue growth is not yet a leading driver of AI investment decisions — top metrics: Sustainability/ESG (39% very helpful, 35% helpful), Scope of AI use (29%, 42%), Long-term strategic impact (24%, 47%), New business models/products (33%, 34%), Customer engagement (25%, 41%), Brand equity (20%, 44%), Cost savings (20%, 40%), Reduction of errors/risks (20%, 37%), Employee productivity (20%, 37%), Revenue growth (19%, 37%).

nodes.label: Investors expect AI to shift from a 'tell me' to a 'show me' story, with current...
nodes.detail: Investors expect AI to shift from a 'tell me' to a 'show me' story, with current disconnects between investments and revenue generation to come under increased scrutiny — this may be years away, not quarters.

nodes.label: Six in ten enterprise architects are increasing their reliance on cloud services...
nodes.detail: Six in ten enterprise architects are increasing their reliance on cloud services for AI, with a shift towards multi-cloud environments for just over a third.

nodes.label: Deployment plans show that companies will turn outwards over the next three year...
nodes.detail: Deployment plans show that companies will turn outwards over the next three years, shifting from internal purposes like operational improvement to external use cases — by 2027, 99% of executives expect GenAI adoption across both internal and external use cases.

nodes.label: 37% of respondents are starting to see more benefits from external rather than i...
nodes.detail: 37% of respondents are starting to see more benefits from external rather than internal use cases, noteworthy given that only 24% of organisations allocate the majority of their investment to external use cases.

nodes.label: Growth and revenue will come for companies that can extract the most value from ...
nodes.detail: Growth and revenue will come for companies that can extract the most value from their data — unstructured data has historically been challenging to process, manage and use, but offers immense value.

nodes.label: Companies report a flywheel effect: continual insights harnessed from data, usin...
nodes.detail: Companies report a flywheel effect: continual insights harnessed from data, using AI, in turn allows them to constantly improve products and services.

nodes.label: McKinsey reckons that more than US$3trn in economic value globally could be gene...
nodes.detail: McKinsey reckons that more than US$3trn in economic value globally could be generated through the enhanced use of open data.

nodes.label: The US DoD has been able to tap into its vast proprietary data to process over 1...
nodes.detail: The US DoD has been able to tap into its vast proprietary data to process over 10 million payment records, allowing it to identify and take action on US$12.7bn in improper payments since 2020.

nodes.label: Organisations need to develop frameworks for establishing investment returns and...
nodes.detail: Organisations need to develop frameworks for establishing investment returns and justifying spend — the largest companies rely heavily on tracking KPIs and conducting post-impact or post-deployment evaluations.

metadata.section: Ch2: Measuring tangible gains from AI

nodes.label: "It cannot be technology for the sake of technology; it has to be tied to value ...
nodes.detail: "It cannot be technology for the sake of technology; it has to be tied to value and impact for the organisation" — Jon Francis, chief data and analytics officer, General Motors.

metadata.section: Ch2: Measuring tangible gains from AI

nodes.label: Opendoor executives determined that productivity should not be the central ROI m...
nodes.detail: Opendoor executives determined that productivity should not be the central ROI measure, instead focusing on top-line growth and improved consumer experience.

metadata.section: Ch2: Measuring tangible gains from AI

nodes.label: Defining ROI requires identifying objectives and establishing realistic timeline...
nodes.detail: Defining ROI requires identifying objectives and establishing realistic timelines for achieving them — many executives expect short-term performances and results, but AI is very hard to institutionalise over the short-term; you need to think over a three-year timeline.

nodes.label: "A significant challenge lies in the fact that the monetisation and business mod...
nodes.detail: "A significant challenge lies in the fact that the monetisation and business models for value creation through GenAI are still not well established — there is uncertainty about whether to invest in general-purpose LLMs or specialised smaller LLMs, and unclear ROI at this stage."

nodes.label: Some algorithms currently used by Dream Sports initially produced negative busin...
nodes.detail: Some algorithms currently used by Dream Sports initially produced negative business metrics — the product and finance teams were nervous, but persistence and education paid off.

nodes.label: In regulated sectors like pharmaceuticals, AI may take five to ten years to dete...
nodes.detail: In regulated sectors like pharmaceuticals, AI may take five to ten years to determine effectiveness once a product's safety is confirmed.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Productivity and efficiency gains are early, measurable wins, but ...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Productivity and efficiency gains are early, measurable wins, but true leaders will seek more ambitious returns — revenue, talent attraction, and novel products and services are among the loftier targets.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Organisations must strike a fine balance between business returns ...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Organisations must strike a fine balance between business returns and the time to achieve true value — experimentation takes time, some projects will inevitably fail, and firms need an initial runway to upgrade their data infrastructure.

nodes.label: As organisations harness AI's potential, they face a critical challenge: their d...
nodes.detail: As organisations harness AI's potential, they face a critical challenge: their data infrastructure is woefully unprepared, akin to having Victorian-era plumbing in a modern building — silos, latency and security are all inhibitors for AI deployment.

nodes.label: One of the biggest shifts in the AI era is not the power of the models themselve...
nodes.detail: One of the biggest shifts in the AI era is not the power of the models themselves, but the underlying plumbing needed to deliver them at scale — many of the world's largest companies are sitting on the technological equivalent of Victorian-era pipes that cannot handle the demands of AI.

nodes.label: Only 22% of organisations say their current architecture is fully capable of sup...
nodes.detail: Only 22% of organisations say their current architecture is fully capable of supporting the unique demands of AI workloads, and just 23% say their current architecture fully integrates AI applications to relevant business data.

nodes.label: Even among the largest companies surveyed, these rates only rise to 28% and 27%,...
nodes.detail: Even among the largest companies surveyed, these rates only rise to 28% and 27%, respectively.

nodes.label: Only 37% of executives and even fewer practitioners (29%) believe that GenAI app...
nodes.detail: Only 37% of executives and even fewer practitioners (29%) believe that GenAI applications at their organisations are production ready.

nodes.label: As much as 90% of data collected by organisations is unstructured and therefore ...
nodes.detail: As much as 90% of data collected by organisations is unstructured and therefore unfit for warehousing — as ML and AI advanced, unstructured data came to be seen as ever more valuable.

nodes.label: Over time, the data lakehouse emerged, combining aspects of both lakes and wareh...
nodes.detail: Over time, the data lakehouse emerged, combining aspects of both lakes and warehouses, built on open-source software using open standards.

nodes.label: Speed is the primary architecture constraint organisations plan to address: real...
nodes.detail: Speed is the primary architecture constraint organisations plan to address: real-time data processing voted the top capacity gap by 47% of respondents, followed by robust data pipelines (42%) and security (39%).

nodes.label: Figure 7: Architecture limitations — Real-time data processing: 47%; Robust data...
nodes.detail: Figure 7: Architecture limitations — Real-time data processing: 47%; Robust data pipelines: 42%; Security: 39%; Integration with downstream systems: 33%; Ethical AI/safety/bias detection: 33%; Efficient model hosting: 31%; Efficient model training: 25%; Scalable compute: 24%.

nodes.label: Finding the right infrastructure can become more difficult as companies get bigg...
nodes.detail: Finding the right infrastructure can become more difficult as companies get bigger — diversified companies with individual business units must determine where the data go, balancing centralisation with flexibility.

nodes.label: Mahindra Group's car company uses a data mesh to store driver relevant informati...
nodes.detail: Mahindra Group's car company uses a data mesh to store driver relevant information such as journey history separately from manufacturing data, while allowing the two datasets to be combined if needed.

nodes.label: Start-ups and digital native companies are not free from infrastructure challeng...
nodes.detail: Start-ups and digital native companies are not free from infrastructure challenges — Dream Sports was still querying production databases for reporting needs several years after founding and only set up a data store once the company had found product-market fit.

nodes.label: Rivian has integrated information from across its complex systems, including sup...
nodes.detail: Rivian has integrated information from across its complex systems, including supply chain, commercial operations and financial departments, into a unified environment, enabling data-driven decision-making at all levels of the organisation.

nodes.label: Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is the process through which an LLM checks ...
nodes.detail: Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is the process through which an LLM checks the answer it has generated against an external source and then refines it — when building their own LLMs, organisations supply internal data as the authoritative source, but this data must be cleaned and prepared for ML.

nodes.label: In their rush to embrace GenAI, many companies are building and maintaining dupl...
nodes.detail: In their rush to embrace GenAI, many companies are building and maintaining duplicates of data or systems to clean and prepare data, adding further complexity to already complicated data infrastructure.

nodes.label: Enterprise architects identified security, data privacy and data silos as the th...
nodes.detail: Enterprise architects identified security, data privacy and data silos as the three biggest challenges faced when managing data for AI applications.

nodes.label: Figure 8: Data gatekeeping challenges — Controlling who can access data: 49%; Pr...
nodes.detail: Figure 8: Data gatekeeping challenges — Controlling who can access data: 49%; Protecting privacy and sensitive information: 42%; Dealing with data silos and lack of integration: 38%; Keeping track of data provenance: 31%; Lack of dedicated resources for data management: 31%; Meeting regulatory compliance: 26%; Ensuring data quality, diversity and representativeness: 25%; Consistent data management across platforms: 25%; Handling large volumes of data efficiently: 19%.

nodes.label: 61% of enterprise architects are increasing their reliance on cloud services to ...
nodes.detail: 61% of enterprise architects are increasing their reliance on cloud services to support AI workloads, with a trend towards multi-cloud solutions among 37%, based on factors including control, security, data ownership, compliance and cost.

nodes.label: Data engineers identified 'simplifying data source connections for ingesting dat...
nodes.detail: Data engineers identified 'simplifying data source connections for ingesting data', 'using a single unified solution instead of multiple tools' and 'better visibility into data pipelines to find and fix issues' as the top interventions for productivity.

nodes.label: GenAI stands out among other uses of data in the technology arsenal for how much...
nodes.detail: GenAI stands out among other uses of data in the technology arsenal for how much upkeep and maintenance it requires — LLMs suffer from model drift over time, as the information they were trained on becomes dated and their performance deteriorates.

nodes.label: Upkeep comes in at least three forms: datasets must be constantly validated for ...
nodes.detail: Upkeep comes in at least three forms: datasets must be constantly validated for completeness, recency and validity; external data sources used by LLMs must be regularly updated; and the models themselves must be constantly tested for efficacy.

nodes.label: Very large firms (revenue over US$10bn) are more likely than others to use ML to...
nodes.detail: Very large firms (revenue over US$10bn) are more likely than others to use ML to detect data anomalies; 'leaders' — companies with production-ready GenAI tools — are also more likely than others to use AI to assess the data.

nodes.label: UPS uses a data mesh to classify data and analytics tools that allow both data s...
nodes.detail: UPS uses a data mesh to classify data and analytics tools that allow both data scientists and business teams to engage in machine learning operations (MLOps).

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Only a fifth of organisations have an architecture fully capable o...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Only a fifth of organisations have an architecture fully capable of supporting AI workloads — real-time data processing is one high-value capability that can only be delivered with an infrastructure refit.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Size or digital savvy is no predictor of success in infrastructure...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Size or digital savvy is no predictor of success in infrastructure transformation — large companies have more complex decisions to make around centralisation and devolution, and digital native firms may have more complex tooling environments.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: AI needs housekeeping — datasets must be constantly validated and ...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: AI needs housekeeping — datasets must be constantly validated and checked for completeness, recency and validity; quality assurance should be applied across data pipelines; external data sources must be regularly updated; and models must be constantly tested for efficacy.

nodes.label: Architects are charged with the design, implementation, and oversight of a scala...
nodes.detail: Architects are charged with the design, implementation, and oversight of a scalable and secure data and AI architecture, requiring a deep understanding of current and emerging technologies.

nodes.label: Only 22% of organisations have architectures that fully support AI workloads wit...
nodes.detail: Only 22% of organisations have architectures that fully support AI workloads without modifications, and only 23% can connect AI applications to relevant business data without changes — architects are tasked with bridging this gap.

nodes.label: Key capability gaps include real-time data processing (identified by nearly half...
nodes.detail: Key capability gaps include real-time data processing (identified by nearly half, 47%); other concerns include data privacy and security breaches; to strengthen governance, architects are focusing on implementing custom APIs (58%), human-in-the-loop processes (55%) and integrating ML models into familiar data tools (52%).

nodes.label: Natural language processing (NLP) is at the forefront of democratisation, with 5...
nodes.detail: Natural language processing (NLP) is at the forefront of democratisation, with 58% of architects believing it will become the primary (or only) tool in data pipeline creation; 67% say the same about workflow development, and 52% about report generation.

nodes.label: Nearly two-thirds of organisations are fully dependent on data engineers for eve...
nodes.detail: Nearly two-thirds of organisations are fully dependent on data engineers for every aspect of data pipeline creation and management, and almost half of data engineers spend most of their time configuring and fixing data source connections.

nodes.label: Data engineers face significant burnout and fatigue given the number of data sou...
nodes.detail: Data engineers face significant burnout and fatigue given the number of data sources and tools required to configure usable data pipelines.

nodes.label: At the top of the wish list for most data and AI teams are simplified data sourc...
nodes.detail: At the top of the wish list for most data and AI teams are simplified data source connections, integrated GenAI tools for coding assistance, and unified platforms to reduce reliance on disparate systems.

nodes.label: Architects are placing significant bets on real-time data processing and robust ...
nodes.detail: Architects are placing significant bets on real-time data processing and robust data pipelines, with nearly 75% identifying one of these as a critical goal.

nodes.label: 46% of companies are migrating a significant number of batch pipelines to real-t...
nodes.detail: 46% of companies are migrating a significant number of batch pipelines to real-time streams in the last year alone.

nodes.label: As foundation models become commoditised, usage will be a baseline, not a boost ...
nodes.detail: As foundation models become commoditised, usage will be a baseline, not a boost — each company must find their edge: their unique recipe of data, need and know-how.

nodes.label: Two-thirds of organisations see significant potential in integrating GenAI model...
nodes.detail: Two-thirds of organisations see significant potential in integrating GenAI models with their own proprietary data — most will mix and match based on workflows and needs.

nodes.label: 58% of data scientists augment their LLMs with proprietary data through RAG, whi...
nodes.detail: 58% of data scientists augment their LLMs with proprietary data through RAG, while 45% use LLMs off the shelf without connecting to their data; 21% do both.

nodes.label: Figure 10: Building and enhancing LLMs with enterprise data — Augmenting with en...
nodes.detail: Figure 10: Building and enhancing LLMs with enterprise data — Augmenting with enterprise/proprietary data (e.g. RAG): 58%; Fine-tuning parameters with enterprise data: 49%; Using LLM as-is without contextual enterprise data: 45%; Pre-training from scratch using enterprise data: 35%; Other (synthetic data, novel tools): 8%.

nodes.label: "Most of the value that you see on AI is buried in the bottom. The top is immedi...
nodes.detail: "Most of the value that you see on AI is buried in the bottom. The top is immediate benefits like productivity, but that's the starting point. You've not gone into your core value chain, that's when you go beneath the iceberg. That is where your proprietary data is."

nodes.label: Financial services respondents were by far the most likely to recognise signific...
nodes.detail: Financial services respondents were by far the most likely to recognise significant potential in integrating GenAI models with proprietary data, with 80% agreeing.

nodes.label: A hybrid approach of utilising both open- and closed-source AI is a common strat...
nodes.detail: A hybrid approach of utilising both open- and closed-source AI is a common strategy — 75% of organisations employ open- and closed-source models based on industry-specific factors, and 89% will do so by 2027.

nodes.label: Closed-source models are typically deployed for internal applications, while ope...
nodes.detail: Closed-source models are typically deployed for internal applications, while open-source models are increasingly used by those expanding into external use-cases.

nodes.label: Reasons for open-source adoption: greater development transparency tops the list...
nodes.detail: Reasons for open-source adoption: greater development transparency tops the list at 52%, followed by access to community resources, opportunity for proprietary IP development, mitigation of vendor lock-in, and greater customisation, privacy and security control.

nodes.label: Superior performance was the leading reason to choose closed-source models at 59...
nodes.detail: Superior performance was the leading reason to choose closed-source models at 59%, followed by user-friendly interfaces and documentation, exclusive features, and seamless integration with existing proprietary systems.

nodes.label: Relatively few companies see merit in developing their own LLM from scratch.
nodes.detail: Relatively few companies see merit in developing their own LLM from scratch.

nodes.label: Accenture helps organisations through its 'switchboard' — a proprietary tool set...
nodes.detail: Accenture helps organisations through its 'switchboard' — a proprietary tool set and framework enabling organisations to decide which models to use based on business use case, relevance, cost, accuracy and latency.

nodes.label: Companies and organisations have access to the best fuel for AI models: the righ...
nodes.detail: Companies and organisations have access to the best fuel for AI models: the right and most relevant data, not merely data sourced from the open internet — Dream Sports found third-party LLMs ineffective because the company's language is too specific.

nodes.label: Higher quality internal data improves the efficiency and performance of models —...
nodes.detail: Higher quality internal data improves the efficiency and performance of models — Rakuten built a deep learning foundation and embeddings using far less processing power because it trains them based on transaction data from its e-commerce site.

nodes.label: Shell is adapting foundational models to work on internal data and also developi...
nodes.detail: Shell is adapting foundational models to work on internal data and also developing its own models by pre-training or fine-tuning LLMs to minimise hallucination risk.

nodes.label: "In the future, the market will move to the use of small private LLMs. But GenAI...
nodes.detail: "In the future, the market will move to the use of small private LLMs. But GenAI is a new technology. We still need to learn how to launch and put initiatives into production in an agile way."

nodes.label: Key takeaway: To unlock value and find their edge, companies will mix and match ...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: To unlock value and find their edge, companies will mix and match off-the-shelf AI with open-source and in-house models — AI will soon be a baseline capability; the organisations that excel will mix and match models to complement their unique data and know-how.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: AI promises to unlock proprietary data that was hitherto hidden or...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: AI promises to unlock proprietary data that was hitherto hidden or dormant — off-the-shelf AI will be useful for low-cost tinkering and lower-value outputs; for true value creation, companies will combine open- and closed-source models.

nodes.label: Data privacy and security breaches are the top concern for 53% of enterprise arc...
nodes.detail: Data privacy and security breaches are the top concern for 53% of enterprise architects, while security and governance are the most challenging aspects of data engineering for engineers (cited by 50% as a top-three challenge).

nodes.label: A 2024 tracker estimated a total of 762 AI legislation documents across 45 state...
nodes.detail: A 2024 tracker estimated a total of 762 AI legislation documents across 45 states in the US alone.

nodes.label: Effective AI governance at an organisation encompasses three components: buildin...
nodes.detail: Effective AI governance at an organisation encompasses three components: building guardrails for what you can and can't do; building mechanisms that enforce those guardrails; and having dedicated data governance functioning as a compliance function ensuring audit and transparency.

nodes.label: Synthetic data, generated using a purpose-built mathematical model or algorithm,...
nodes.detail: Synthetic data, generated using a purpose-built mathematical model or algorithm, can help solve data science tasks — it can improve performance and reliability by providing a larger volume of more diverse data for training, such as including underrepresented data classes.

nodes.label: Synthetic data remains an untapped resource, with only 7.5% of data scientists u...
nodes.detail: Synthetic data remains an untapped resource, with only 7.5% of data scientists utilising it in their GenAI projects.

nodes.label: RAG is another useful technique to control quality and enrich knowledge — Rakute...
nodes.detail: RAG is another useful technique to control quality and enrich knowledge — Rakuten's GenAI models retrieve real-time inventory and pricing information to incorporate the latest information into applications such as search, recommendation systems, and adverts.

nodes.label: Fanatics Betting & Gaming uses AI and GenAI models to detect and enhance governa...
nodes.detail: Fanatics Betting & Gaming uses AI and GenAI models to detect and enhance governance issues related to responsible gaming — nudging users with excessive spend into free-to-play games or encouraging them to take a timeout.

nodes.label: 40% of respondents acknowledged that their organisation's processes to ensure AI...
nodes.detail: 40% of respondents acknowledged that their organisation's processes to ensure AI safety and compliance are insufficient.

nodes.label: Figure 13: Governance sufficiency by region — India (35% strongly agree), US (29...
nodes.detail: Figure 13: Governance sufficiency by region — India (35% strongly agree), US (29% strongly agree), UK (24% strongly agree), South Korea (21% strongly agree), France (20%), Germany (20%), ASEAN (20%), Japan (12%), Australia (14%).

nodes.label: Centres of Excellence (COEs) are emerging as a popular approach to achieving sys...
nodes.detail: Centres of Excellence (COEs) are emerging as a popular approach to achieving systematic AI oversight — they have become key enablers of AI-driven insights and use cases within organisations.

nodes.label: COEs monitor, implement and share best practices for implementation across depar...
nodes.detail: COEs monitor, implement and share best practices for implementation across departments and business units; they also foster exploration and innovation for building and operationalising AI.

nodes.label: COEs are not just brakes on AI — they can be a 'forcing function' for AI deliver...
nodes.detail: COEs are not just brakes on AI — they can be a 'forcing function' for AI delivery across the enterprise, bringing together departments from HR and legal to tech teams to unlock potential.

nodes.label: Shell's Analytics COE brings together multi-faceted teams and supports a communi...
nodes.detail: Shell's Analytics COE brings together multi-faceted teams and supports a community of hundreds of data scientists and thousands of 'AI enthusiasts'.

nodes.label: Technically, COEs develop, 'productionise' and monitor AI models with a lens on ...
nodes.detail: Technically, COEs develop, 'productionise' and monitor AI models with a lens on business impact and returns — they oversee core operations including data and ML, and seek architecture and infrastructure optimisations for operational efficiencies.

nodes.label: "With GenAI, there is an opportunity to revisit an entire business process and r...
nodes.detail: "With GenAI, there is an opportunity to revisit an entire business process and reimagine what it could be. It encourages leaders to challenge past decisions and accept that there may be a newer, better way."

nodes.label: Many business leaders emphasise that AI adoption will not lead to layoffs — AI m...
nodes.detail: Many business leaders emphasise that AI adoption will not lead to layoffs — AI means more efficiency in business, which means we can create more stories, not by automating mundane tasks but by doing more with the number of people we have.

nodes.label: As mass AI adoption takes hold, there will be more demand for specialised roles ...
nodes.detail: As mass AI adoption takes hold, there will be more demand for specialised roles like data scientists, developers and MLOps experts — workers who acquire AI skills see wages rise by an average of 21%.

nodes.label: One 2030 forecast estimates that 375 million workers may need to switch occupati...
nodes.detail: One 2030 forecast estimates that 375 million workers may need to switch occupations as their line of work is disrupted by digitalisation, automation and AI.

nodes.label: Only one in six firms are confident in their ability to attract the expertise ne...
nodes.detail: Only one in six firms are confident in their ability to attract the expertise needed to take full advantage of AI technologies — those who succeed are deploying AI at a much faster rate.

nodes.label: More than 97% of enterprise architects predict that NLP will either supplement o...
nodes.detail: More than 97% of enterprise architects predict that NLP will either supplement or replace traditional methods for pipeline creation and workflow orchestration.

nodes.label: Unilever has trained almost 20,000 people in the use of GenAI — a vital step for...
nodes.detail: Unilever has trained almost 20,000 people in the use of GenAI — a vital step for a company operating in a dynamic sector where demand for new skills and competencies is rising.

nodes.label: Some firms are embedding AI tools into office software to ease workloads — Rivia...
nodes.detail: Some firms are embedding AI tools into office software to ease workloads — Rivian's 'North Star is to democratise data' so everyone at the company should be able to leverage data that drives decisions without being a data engineer or data scientist.

nodes.label: The Repsol Artificial Intelligence Products programme hands employees the keys t...
nodes.detail: The Repsol Artificial Intelligence Products programme hands employees the keys to AI, letting them tackle complex data tasks solo, without technical knowledge — tools promise autonomy and agility, turning its workforce into 'citizen data scientists'.

nodes.label: The biggest data management challenges identified by architects include controll...
nodes.detail: The biggest data management challenges identified by architects include controlling data access (49%) and protecting sensitive data (42%).

nodes.label: Human judgement will remain critical for monitoring AI's outputs, and companies ...
nodes.detail: Human judgement will remain critical for monitoring AI's outputs, and companies must calibrate the right mix of people and machines — two-thirds of organisations say they are actively experimenting to find the right balance between humans and AI, and 80% say these efforts could be stronger.

nodes.label: "Individuals using GenAI must have the ability to independently evaluate its out...
nodes.detail: "Individuals using GenAI must have the ability to independently evaluate its outputs and handle them responsibly."

nodes.label: In sensitive sectors with high-risk profiles and low risk appetites, computer-ge...
nodes.detail: In sensitive sectors with high-risk profiles and low risk appetites, computer-generated errors will often provoke strong negative perceptions — tolerance for errors and disparities in AI is understandably lower compared with tolerance for human professionals.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Data innovations enhance AI governance — techniques like synthetic...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Data innovations enhance AI governance — techniques like synthetic data and RAG help organisations address data limitations, reduce bias and improve AI system quality.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Centres of Excellence (COEs) drive systematic AI oversight — COEs ...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Centres of Excellence (COEs) drive systematic AI oversight — COEs act as central control units for AI implementation, monitoring best practices and fostering innovation across departments.

nodes.label: Key takeaway: Balancing human expertise with AI capabilities is crucial — organi...
nodes.detail: Key takeaway: Balancing human expertise with AI capabilities is crucial — organisations are focusing on upskilling employees and creating self-service AI tools to democratise data usage, but human judgement remains critical for monitoring AI outputs and handling sensitive data.

nodes.label: Internal use cases and pilots are the necessary testing ground — experts advocat...
nodes.detail: Internal use cases and pilots are the necessary testing ground — experts advocate internal use cases initially, through sandboxes and iteration; pilot selection should be determined by risk thresholds, to solve clear problems and within well-defined scopes.

nodes.label: Fixing the plumbing: to build a robust data and technical foundation, companies ...
nodes.detail: Fixing the plumbing: to build a robust data and technical foundation, companies need to invest in an infrastructure refit to support high-volume, varied data — the rigid data storage systems of yesteryear cannot manage the diversity of data, real-time usage and wider utilisation in this more democratised era.

nodes.label: Larger companies and conglomerates especially must decide the right balance betw...
nodes.detail: Larger companies and conglomerates especially must decide the right balance between centralisation and devolution as they look to harness cloud platforms.

nodes.label: AI needs KPIs — to avoid profligate spending and the inevitable trough of disill...
nodes.detail: AI needs KPIs — to avoid profligate spending and the inevitable trough of disillusionment, companies need to develop intelligent ROI metrics and a disciplined approach to spending.

nodes.label: Productivity, cost control, revenue per worker, user experience and reduced staf...
nodes.detail: Productivity, cost control, revenue per worker, user experience and reduced staff burnout are all meaningful metrics — the most successful will use AI to drive new revenue streams and business model innovation.

nodes.label: Use flexible timeframes for achieving returns — KPIs and metrics matter, but com...
nodes.detail: Use flexible timeframes for achieving returns — KPIs and metrics matter, but companies should not necessarily seek quick returns; experiments involve wrong turns and tinkering.

nodes.label: Companies in heavily regulated sectors like healthcare have to operate within st...
nodes.detail: Companies in heavily regulated sectors like healthcare have to operate within structured systems of regulatory oversight — there is also merit in 'watchful waiting' as the AI product and service ecosystem evolves.

nodes.label: Use a mix of models to sharpen your edge: in-house data and organisational know-...
nodes.detail: Use a mix of models to sharpen your edge: in-house data and organisational know-how — in highly specialised industries, off-the-shelf models will fall short of quality and compliance requirements.

nodes.label: Companies can mix and match open- and closed-source AI, and private or public cl...
nodes.detail: Companies can mix and match open- and closed-source AI, and private or public cloud, based on performance, governance, cost and capacity, to find the right blend.

nodes.label: Establish robust governance frameworks — organisations need clear guidelines, pr...
nodes.detail: Establish robust governance frameworks — organisations need clear guidelines, protocols and oversight mechanisms, and institutional innovations like Centres of Excellence (COEs), to manage AI deployment and mitigate potential risks.

nodes.label: COEs can also be a forcing function for improving co-ordination and coherence ov...
nodes.detail: COEs can also be a forcing function for improving co-ordination and coherence overall — technical innovations like synthetic data and RAG can also strengthen model performance.

nodes.label: It is crucial to recognise the importance of human oversight of AI systems, espe...
nodes.detail: It is crucial to recognise the importance of human oversight of AI systems, especially in high-stakes domains.

nodes.label: Calibrate human versus machine — engaging with employees in the design and deplo...
nodes.detail: Calibrate human versus machine — engaging with employees in the design and deployment of AI systems is critical to secure buy-in and adoption; communicating how AI can help workers rather than carry out their work for them.

nodes.label: New skills and competencies can be developed through bite-size programmes and ex...
nodes.detail: New skills and competencies can be developed through bite-size programmes and exercises, with companies bridging the gap between AI specialists and the workforce.

nodes.label: AI should also be integrated into leadership programmes — organisations should e...
nodes.detail: AI should also be integrated into leadership programmes — organisations should encourage a critical outlook to avoid automation bias and keep human judgement at the fore.

nodes.label: Figure 3: Stage of GenAI implementation by country — India: 56% expanding; Franc...
nodes.detail: Figure 3: Stage of GenAI implementation by country — India: 56% expanding; France: 41% expanding; UK: 37% expanding; ASEAN: 28% expanding; US: 27% expanding; South Korea: 26% expanding; Germany: 21% expanding; Australia: 18% expanding; Other Europe: 11% expanding; Japan: 6% expanding.

nodes.label: Figure 5: GenAI internal vs external use cases — Internal current: 22% expanding...
nodes.detail: Figure 5: GenAI internal vs external use cases — Internal current: 22% expanding, 42% deploying, 34% exploring; Internal 2027: 66% expanding, 27% deploying, 6% exploring; External current: 12% expanding, 24% deploying, 54% exploring; External 2027: 35% expanding, 53% deploying, 11% exploring.

nodes.label: Figure 6: GenAI use cases with most investment — Mostly internal: 23%, Equal: 53...
nodes.detail: Figure 6: GenAI use cases with most investment — Mostly internal: 23%, Equal: 53%, Mostly external: 24%. GenAI use cases with most benefit — Mostly internal: 17%, Equal: 46%, Mostly external: 37%.

nodes.label: Figure 11: Upside of proprietary data by industry — Financial services: 80% agre...
nodes.detail: Figure 11: Upside of proprietary data by industry — Financial services: 80% agree; Telecoms: 72% agree; Retail: 70% agree; Healthcare: 66% agree; Manufacturing: 66% agree; Government: 63% agree; Media: 55% agree; Energy: 55% agree; Total: 66% agree.

nodes.label: Figure 12: Adoption of GenAI models by type — Training custom model on own data:...
nodes.detail: Figure 12: Adoption of GenAI models by type — Training custom model on own data: 32% in production; Fine-tuning open-source: 29% in production; Using AI embedded in software: 37% in production; Building with APIs: 27% in production; Serving open-source model: 25% in production; Licensing commercial model: 25% in production; BYOAI/governing employee use of public models: 18% in production.

nodes.label: Salesforce (2024)
nodes.detail: The Agentic Enterprise - The IT Architecture for the AI-Powered Future

nodes.label: To realize the vision of AI-powered enterprises, organizations must undergo a bu...
nodes.detail: To realize the vision of AI-powered enterprises, organizations must undergo a business and IT transformation to become Agentic Enterprises.

nodes.label: Today's traditional enterprises face operational challenges: information siloes,...
nodes.detail: Today's traditional enterprises face operational challenges: information siloes, employees buried in manual work, misaligned incentives in organizational structures, and disjointed feedback loops between strategies and outcomes.

nodes.label: While traditional architecture may support sub-scale deployments of AI agents to...
nodes.detail: While traditional architecture may support sub-scale deployments of AI agents today, it cannot fully deliver the business capabilities.

nodes.label: Embedding this functionality directly in today's static and deterministic applic...
nodes.detail: Embedding this functionality directly in today's static and deterministic application architecture would introduce unnecessary architectural complexity and risk.

nodes.label: An Agentic Enterprise is an organization integrating intelligent AI agents with ...
nodes.detail: An Agentic Enterprise is an organization integrating intelligent AI agents with human workers as digital colleagues.

nodes.label: Augmented Human Productivity: Automation of repetitive work frees human workers ...
nodes.detail: Augmented Human Productivity: Automation of repetitive work frees human workers to focus on higher-value creative and strategic tasks.

nodes.label: Adaptive Capability Improvement: Observable agent reasoning enables continuous i...
nodes.detail: Adaptive Capability Improvement: Observable agent reasoning enables continuous improvement of enterprise capabilities through feedback loops.

nodes.label: Elastic Workforce Capacity: AI agents handle workload surges dynamically, provid...
nodes.detail: Elastic Workforce Capacity: AI agents handle workload surges dynamically, providing elastic scaling of workforce capacity beyond human headcount limits.

nodes.label: Predictive Operational Resilience: 24/7 autonomous risk management through agent...
nodes.detail: Predictive Operational Resilience: 24/7 autonomous risk management through agents that continuously monitor and predict operational disruptions.

nodes.label: Autonomous Process Execution: Agents execute business processes at machine speed...
nodes.detail: Autonomous Process Execution: Agents execute business processes at machine speed with consistent quality, removing human bottlenecks from routine workflows.

nodes.label: Transboundary Orchestration: Agents orchestrate work across organizational silos...
nodes.detail: Transboundary Orchestration: Agents orchestrate work across organizational silos, breaking down departmental boundaries that limit traditional process automation.

nodes.label: The document introduces an expanded IT architecture replacing traditional 5-laye...
nodes.detail: The document introduces an expanded IT architecture replacing traditional 5-layer models with an 11-layer framework designed for the agentic enterprise.

nodes.label: Layer 1 — Experience Layer: Multimodal human interfaces providing conversational...
nodes.detail: Layer 1 — Experience Layer: Multimodal human interfaces providing conversational AI, attribution transparency, proactive notifications, omnichannel experiences, and context-aware personalization.

nodes.label: The Experience Layer enables humans to interact with agents through natural lang...
nodes.detail: The Experience Layer enables humans to interact with agents through natural language, visual interfaces, and proactive alerts rather than traditional form-based UIs.

nodes.label: Layer 2 — Agentic Layer: Agent lifecycle management including runtime environmen...
nodes.detail: Layer 2 — Agentic Layer: Agent lifecycle management including runtime environments, reasoning engines, memory stores, interoperability protocols, and tool registries.

nodes.label: The Agentic Layer manages the full lifecycle of AI agents from creation through ...
nodes.detail: The Agentic Layer manages the full lifecycle of AI agents from creation through deployment, execution, and retirement, providing the core runtime for autonomous operations.

nodes.label: Layer 3 — AI/ML Layer: Centralized intelligence hub managing foundation models, ...
nodes.detail: Layer 3 — AI/ML Layer: Centralized intelligence hub managing foundation models, RAG pipelines, trust/safety frameworks, model gateways, development workbenches, and serving infrastructure.

nodes.label: AI agents fundamentally rely on AI models, requiring sophisticated lifecycle man...
nodes.detail: AI agents fundamentally rely on AI models, requiring sophisticated lifecycle management separate from traditional application architecture.

nodes.label: AI models should be treated as shared enterprise capabilities with unified lifec...
nodes.detail: AI models should be treated as shared enterprise capabilities with unified lifecycle tooling and governance, not embedded within individual applications.

nodes.label: Layer 4 — Enterprise Orchestration Layer: Blended orchestration combining decent...
nodes.detail: Layer 4 — Enterprise Orchestration Layer: Blended orchestration combining decentralized choreography with centralized oversight, process governance, shared memory management, and digital twin capabilities.

nodes.label: Agents need novel orchestration capabilities for complex, dynamic workflows — ca...
nodes.detail: Agents need novel orchestration capabilities for complex, dynamic workflows — capabilities that exceed existing automation tools designed for linear, deterministic processes.

nodes.label: Hybrid orchestration combines centralized governance with decentralized agent ch...
nodes.detail: Hybrid orchestration combines centralized governance with decentralized agent choreography, allowing agents to coordinate autonomously within governed boundaries.

nodes.label: Layer 5 — Application & App Services Layer: Modular application services exposin...
nodes.detail: Layer 5 — Application & App Services Layer: Modular application services exposing business logic as composable tools, with agent embedding SDKs and dynamic UI generation.

nodes.label: Business logic must be exposed as composable, agent-consumable tools rather than...
nodes.detail: Business logic must be exposed as composable, agent-consumable tools rather than locked inside monolithic applications.

nodes.label: Layer 6 — Semantic Layer: Enterprise Knowledge Graph (EKG) providing unified dat...
nodes.detail: Layer 6 — Semantic Layer: Enterprise Knowledge Graph (EKG) providing unified data understanding through metadata services, business glossaries, semantic models, and reasoning engines.

nodes.label: Enterprise Knowledge Graphs are critical for providing unified semantic understa...
nodes.detail: Enterprise Knowledge Graphs are critical for providing unified semantic understanding across domains, enabling agents to reason over enterprise concepts consistently.

nodes.label: Agents need common semantic functionality across organizational silos to operate...
nodes.detail: Agents need common semantic functionality across organizational silos to operate effectively in multi-domain contexts.

nodes.label: Layer 7 — Data Layer: Unified data foundation featuring vector databases, data l...
nodes.detail: Layer 7 — Data Layer: Unified data foundation featuring vector databases, data lakehouses, zero-copy federation, master data management, and AI-specialized stores.

nodes.label: The Data Layer provides the unified data foundation that agents require, includi...
nodes.detail: The Data Layer provides the unified data foundation that agents require, including specialized AI-ready stores like vector databases alongside traditional data infrastructure.

nodes.label: Layer 8 — Infrastructure Layer: Cloud-native compute supporting elastic scaling,...
nodes.detail: Layer 8 — Infrastructure Layer: Cloud-native compute supporting elastic scaling, hybrid/multi-cloud deployment, edge AI, self-healing systems, and sustainable computing.

nodes.detail: Principle 5 — Agent-first with human oversight: Agents should be the default tool approach for executing work, with human intervention capability preserved for high-stakes decisions.

nodes.detail: Principle 6 — Reactive and multimodal interaction: Event-driven and real-time processing across multiple data formats and interaction modalities.

nodes.detail: Open standards and interoperability (MCP, A2A protocols) are essential to avoid vendor lock-in and enable a heterogeneous agent ecosystem.

nodes.detail: Organizations should establish foundation layers (data governance, semantic models, AI/ML centralization, observability) before deploying agents at scale.

nodes.detail: Level 1 — Information Retrieval Agents: Trustworthy data-to-agent pipelines with VectorDB, Model Gateway, business glossaries, and transparency UI. Agents retrieve and surface information but do not take autonomous actions.

nodes.label: Level 3 — Multi-Domain Orchestration: Cross-cutting enterprise architecture feat...
nodes.detail: Level 3 — Multi-Domain Orchestration: Cross-cutting enterprise architecture featuring Enterprise Knowledge Graph, event-driven integration fabric, AIOps, and policy-as-code. Agents coordinate across multiple business domains.

nodes.label: The maturity model recommends a phased approach, starting with information retri...
nodes.detail: The maturity model recommends a phased approach, starting with information retrieval (Level 1), progressing through single-domain orchestration (Level 2), then multi-domain orchestration (Level 3), before achieving full multi-agent enterprise orchestration (Level 4).

nodes.detail: The Semantic Layer (Enterprise Knowledge Graph) is the most critical differentiator between traditional and agentic architectures, providing the shared understanding that agents need to operate across domains.

nodes.detail: Hybrid orchestration — combining centralized governance with decentralized agent choreography — is the correct orchestration model for agentic enterprises.

nodes.detail: Agent-based architectures require fundamentally different observability, security, and governance approaches compared to deterministic application architectures.

nodes.detail: AI models should be managed as shared enterprise capabilities, not embedded within individual applications, requiring a dedicated AI/ML layer separate from the application layer.

nodes.detail: Enterprise architects drive the transformation to agentic enterprises through strategic investment decisions that enable organizations to realize the value from new business capabilities.

nodes.label: The 3-5 year timeframe for agentic enterprise transformation reflects the scale ...
nodes.detail: The 3-5 year timeframe for agentic enterprise transformation reflects the scale of foundational changes needed in data, semantics, and infrastructure before agents can operate at scale.
